captions.text:
A tropical rainforest without rain wouldn't
be much of a rainforest. I mean, all plants

need water to grow, and without it, they shrivel
up and die. So what about the ancient Hawai'ian

proverb,"Hahai no ka ua i ka ulula`au", which
means "the rain follows after the forest"?
How could that be?

Well, all land plants lose water when the
pores on their leaves open up during photosynthesis,

and this evaporation draws more water up through
their stems. With so much rain soaking the

soil in rainforests, water is nearly unlimited,
and accordingly, rain forest trees can afford

to move and lose more water than other plants.
All that water vapor rising from the forest

feeds moisture-laden clouds while causing
convection - together, these effects accelerate

the formation of rain - which falls to the
soil and gets taken up all over again.

This cycle--absorption, evaporation, rain--
happens everywhere there are plants. However,

super-wet soil, fast-pumping trees and hot
tropical sun make the cycle so fast in the

rainforest that - unlike other biomes where
clouds might form in one place and rain in

another - all that water stays in the same
region.

So without the forest pumping so much water
into the air, rainforests wouldn't be as rainy.

And without so much rain, the forest couldn't
pump so much water into the air. So which
came first, the rain, or the rainforest?

Well, before rain forests, ancestors of trees
like cypress, pine and spruce dominated the

land - but they were conservative when it
came to using (and losing) water - so the
air tended to be dry, meaning less rain.

However, around 130 million years ago, a new
kind of plant developed that took the risk

of losing more water in return for souped-up
photosynthesis - these were the flowering

plants, and their risk paid off: their faster
growth enabled them to out-compete the ancestral

pines and take over the tropical regions of
the globe.

Angiosperms lost so much water into the air
that as they spread, they brought their own

rain with them. And today, tropical rainforests
receive more rain than if they were replaced

by pine forests- in some places as much as
a meter more rain each year. That's equivalent

to an extra two and a half hours of heavy
rain every week. Not surprisingly, all that

water cools off the forest, too, which is
why the Amazon isn't nearly as hot as the

Sahara or even an east Texas pine forest in
summer.

But the hot, dry tropics of the past may soon
be a part of our future. In parts of the Amazon

where vast swaths of rainforest have been
logged or cleared for agriculture, weather

stations are already observing decreased rainfall,
and forest fires have become more frequent.

Scientists worry that these changes will lead
to ever hotter, drier and more flammable tropics

in the coming decades, making things tougher
both for the remaining forest and for the

people who live there. So, when in drought,
plant a tree. Seriously - Hahai no ka ua i
ka ulula`au (the rain follows after the forest).

title: Which Came First - The Rain or the Rainforest?

comments.author: Nazlee Singh

comments.text:
+Nazlee Singh There's just so much water in the atmosphere there that it 
falls within minutes or hours of transpiration. Other areas with much lower 
amounts of water in the atmosphere can take days for the concentration to 
get high enough to fall. By then the air mass has moved on.

comments.author: Seth Blatt

comments.text:
+Seth Blatt With "needed" I mean that the animals that weren't born with 
some kind of structural strength in their bodies died because they had a 
disadvantage (survival of the fittest). Humans don't "need" three arms to 
survive, so anyone born with three arms will not have an advantage. And 
because it would be quite disturbing, that person would likely not have 
children so the "three arm gene" would be lost. To answer your question 
about the balls, let's say we have a creature with two bones, the bones 
will indeed rub together and be damaged, if a gene mutation makes some kind 
of protecting tissue in between those bones. That creature will have an 
advantage and will be more likely to pass on it's genes. As more and more 
positive mutations occur, the tissue will become stronger and eventually 
take a shape which gives the most strength and flexibility (which is a bal 
apparently). I would like to remember you how long 4,6 billion years is, 
the craziest things can evolve in such a long time. To wrap it up, I leave 
many unanswered questions simply because I am not a biologist. I would like 
to compliment your critical view on this subject. But I would like to leave 
it at this. It was an interesting discussion, but if you want to continue, 
I suggest you contact an actual biologist and not some random kid on the 
internet :). Goodbye
comments.author: The Mister Y Pig

comments.text:
+The Mister Y Pig interesting... if muscles were working just fine how 
could bones come into play, WHERE did bones come from? so you say "needs" 
as if evolution can provide whatever is needed.. what if all humans said 
they "needed" three arms? lastly, how could multiple bones rubbing together 
create balls and sockets for those balls? you leave many unanswered 
questions.
comments.author: Seth Blatt

comments.text:
uhm, Well since it would be quite stupid for a life form to evolve bones 
first and then muscle I would say muscle. A creature without any form of 
muscle would not be able to move (btw i'm talking about animal life, not 
plant life that's a different story. As a life form gets bigger it needs 
bones for structural strength. Probably the first boned creature had only 
one bone, a spine or something. So when more bones were required as the 
creature evolves, bone joints were required too. So I think muscles evolved 
first and then bone joints. I don't know if I'm right, I didn't google any 
of this but I just wanted to show you things like this can be 'solved' with 
logic (what I just said was a hypothesis, to solve the problem you would 
have to look at fossils). I hope that sort of answers your question, have a 
nice day :)

comments.author: Crick1952

comments.text:
They're mostly in the tropics because deciduous trees need the winters to 
not be too long & harsh, because they lose all their leaves when it gets 
cold & thus, no photosynthesis (tree eating).

As for how they begin, think of it like a sort of snowball effect.  Think 
of an area which already gets a moderate amount of rain.  Some plants start 
to grow there, & they pump a little more water into the air, so there's a 
little more rain -- it proceeds like that.

O yea and another thing. Eat a bit less meat (and milk). 1 kilo of meat

to meat drives up prices of these crops, inserting more pressure on 
farmland expansion, and thereby on deforestation of tropical rainforests. 
Just a little thing we all can do, to save these amazing forests.﻿

comments.text:
Well! Turns out the trees cause the rain in a rainforest, not the abundant

comments.author: Joe Immler

comments.text: "Plant [the right] tree", since the wrong tree would be worse still!!!﻿
comments.author: sion8

comments.text:
I have to be honest here, it's not just Rainforest trees, but most all 
other types of heavy old growth vegetation areas attract cloud formation 
and rainfall, but they act as a catalyst for capturing moisture from such 
events as monsoonal season air movement. Old Growth Chaparral is a huge 
cloud formation magnet in Southern California. But such potential is 
diminishing like the rainforests with mega-wildfires destroying the old 
growth ecosystems﻿
comments.author: Kevin Franck

comments.text:
When in doubt, plant a tree!
